August 31, 2014: Fiction
COLORLESS TSUKURU TAZAKI AND HIS YEARS OF PILGRIMAGE, by Haruki
Murakami. (Knopf.) A young man’s difficult coming-of-age.
LOVE LETTERS, by Debbie Macomber. (Ballantine.) Three couples struggle with
intimacy one summer at Cedar Cove’s Rose Harbor Inn.
THE 6TH EXTINCTION, by James Rollins. (Morrow/HarperCollins.) The 10th
Sigma Force novel offers Nazis, an ancient secret, a ticking nuclear clock and
alien life-forms.
BIG LITTLE LIES, by Liane Moriarty. (Amy Einhorn/Putnam.) Who will end up
dead, and how, when three mothers with children in the same school become
friends?
THE GOLDFINCH, by Donna Tartt. (Little, Brown.)  A painting becomes a boy’s
prize, guilt and burden.
THE HEIST, by Daniel Silva. (Harper.) Gabriel Allon, an art restorer and
occasional spy for the Israeli secret service, must track down a famous missing
painting by Caravaggio.
THE BOOK OF LIFE, by Deborah Harkness. (Viking.) In the conclusion to the All
Souls trilogy, the Oxford scholar/witch Diana Bishop and the vampire geneticist
Matthew Clairmont return from Elizabethan London to the present.
ALL THE LIGHT WE CANNOT SEE, by Anthony Doerr. (Scribner.) The lives of a
blind French girl and a gadget-obsessed German boy before and during World
War II.
THE LOST ISLAND, by Douglas Preston and Lincoln Child. (Grand Central.)
Gideon Crew, scientist and thief, pursues an extraordinary treasure for his
mysterious employer.
THE MAGICIAN'S LAND, by Lev Grossman. (Viking.) Quentin, an exiled magician,
tries a risky heist in the final installment of a trilogy.
TOM CLANCY: SUPPORT AND DEFEND, by Mark Greaney. (Putnam.) A
Dominic Caruso novel, written in the tradition of Clancy, who died in October 2013.
THE SILKWORM, by Robert Galbraith. (Mulholland/Little, Brown.) The private
detective Cormoran Strike in literary London; by J. K. Rowling, writing
pseudonymously.
FOOL'S ASSASSIN, by Robin Hobb. (Del Rey.) In the first novel of a new fantasy
trilogy, Fitz and the Fool, the hero of the Farseer trilogy is living under an assumed
name.
August 31, 2014
Non-Fiction
AMERICA, by Dinesh D'Souza. (Regnery.) A defense of America against the view
that its power in the world should be diminished; also a documentary film.
ONE NATION, by Ben Carson with Candy Carson. (Sentinel.) Carson, a retired
pediatric neurosurgeon, now a Fox News contributor, offers solutions to problems.
IN THE KINGDOM OF ICE, by Hampton Sides. (Doubleday.) An 1879 polar
voyage gone terribly wrong.
THE FIRST FAMILY DETAIL, by Ronald Kessler. (Crown Forum.) A reporter
divulges details from Secret Service agents about the lives of presidents, ex-
presidents and candidates, as well as about the service’s failings.
DAVID AND GOLIATH, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown.) How disadvantages
can work in our favor.
A SPY AMONG FRIENDS, by Ben Macintyre. (Crown.) An account of the British
Cold War spy Kim Philby focuses on the two close friends whose trust he
betrayed.
HARD CHOICES, by Hillary Rodham Clinton. (Simon & Schuster.) Clinton’s
memoir focuses on her years as secretary of state.
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House.) An Olympic runner’s story
of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
BLOOD FEUD, by Edward Klein. (Regnery.) A journalist describes animosity
behind the alliance between the Clinton and Obama families.
THE INVISIBLE BRIDGE, by Rick Perlstein. (Simon & Schuster.) Society and
politics in America from 1973 to 1976, the years between Nixon’s resignation and
the beginning of Ronald Reagan’s ascent.
CAPITAL IN THE TWENTY-FIRST CENTURY, by Thomas Piketty.
(Belknap/Harvard University.) A French economist’s analysis of centuries of
economic history predicts worsening inequality and proposes solutions.
I AM MALALA, by Malala Yousafzai with Christina Lamb. (Little, Brown.) The
experience of the young Pakistani advocate for women’s education shot by the
Taliban.
THINK LIKE A FREAK, by Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner.
(Morrow/HarperCollins.) How to solve problems creatively, from the authors of
“Freakonomics.”
THE MOCKINGBIRD NEXT DOOR, by Marja Mills. (Penguin Press.) The author’s
experience as Harper Lee’s neighbor.
